translation.en: [Amber Straughn] After the Big Bang, the universe was just filled
translation.ko: 빅뱅 이후 우주는 그저 어마어마한 수프로 꽉 차 있었어요

translation.en: with this sort of cosmic soup of hydrogen and helium gas.
translation.ko: 우주는 그저 어마어마한 수프로 꽉 차 있었어요 수소와 헬륨 기체로 된 수프요

translation.en: Eventually, those hydrogen and helium atoms
started to form together to fuse stars.
The stars were probably grouped into galaxies.
translation.ko: 그 별들이 무리 지어 은하가 되었겠죠

translation.en: That was what we call the first light.
[Mike Menzel] To see first light, the first, uh, galaxies in our universe,
translation.ko: 최초의 빛이 보이고 우리 우주의 첫 은하가 보이는

translation.en: that distant past is where creation happened.
[Amber] When we look at the sky, beyond the stars in our Milky Way,
translation.ko: 우리 은하계 별들 너머 저 하늘을 보면

translation.en: we can only see darkness.
We've never had the technology
to see that first part of the story of the universe.
translation.ko: 우주 이야기의 시작을 볼 만큼 기술이 발달하지 못했었죠

translation.en: To be able to look back in time
to see the very first light,
you need the most complex telescope in history.
[Thomas] Webb, in the whole history of NASA, is the riskiest mission ever done.
translation.ko: 웹 망원경은 NASA 역사상 위험 부담이 가장 큰 임무예요

translation.en: [reporter] This mission could be a technological triumph
translation.ko: 이 임무는 기술적인 승리일 수도 있고

translation.en: or a heartbreaking disaster.
[Mike Menzel] We're putting the largest telescope in space, a million miles away.
translation.ko: 160만 킬로미터 떨어진 우주에 가장 큰 망원경을 내보내는 거죠

translation.en: You know, you can think of a thousand things that can go wrong.
[Thomas] It's the largest number of single point failures
of any mission ever done.
[Amber] To try to think the unthinkable of, "If it doesn't work…"
translation.ko: '실패하면 어쩌지'라는 생각할 수도 없는 일을 생각해요

translation.en: [Amber] It's a scary thought, for sure.
[Mike] Any successful mission systems engineer
translation.ko: 성공한 임무의 시스템 엔지니어가 운은 무관하다고 생각한다면

translation.en: who doesn't think there was luck involved is either a fool or a liar.
translation.ko: 성공한 임무의 시스템 엔지니어가 운은 무관하다고 생각한다면 바보거나 거짓말쟁이예요

translation.en: [Amber] Those first images will help us get closer to answering those questions of,
translation.ko: 첫 이미지를 입수하게 되면 여러 질문의 답에 가까워지겠죠

translation.en: "Where do we come from?"
"How did we get here?"
"Are we alone?"
That's our history, right there.
-[Bill Nelson] It is our whole history. -[Thomas] Our whole history right there.
translation.ko: - 우리의 역사 전체죠 - 역사 전체가 여기 담겨 있어요

translation.en: [Amber] I have no doubt that this telescope is our next giant leap
translation.ko: 이 망원경이 생명 탐사에서 아주 큰 도약이 될 거라고

translation.en: in our search for life.
The universe is so big,
there's got to be evolved conscious life out there.
translation.ko: 의식이 있고 진화된 생명체가 어딘가에 꼭 있을 거예요

translation.en: The James Webb Space Telescope
will fundamentally change the way we understand the universe.
translation.ko: 우리가 우주를 이해하는 방식을 완전히 바꿔 놓을 거예요

translation.en: [reporter 1] There's a new telescope in town.
[reporter 2] The James Webb Space Telescope,
translation.ko: 나사 두 번째 국장의 이름을 딴

translation.en: named after the second administrator of NASA, is about to become a reality.
translation.ko: 제임스 웹 우주 망원경이 곧 현실이 됩니다

translation.en: It's going to be launching from French Guiana, a spaceport there,
which is a reminder that this is not just a NASA mission.
translation.ko: 즉, 미국 항공 우주국 나사만의 임무가 아니라

translation.en: It is a joint mission with the European Space Agency
and the Canadian Space Agency.
Three decades and ten billion dollars in the making,
the project hasn't been without controversy.
Multiple mishaps, budget crises,
even a threatened congressional cancellation.
The launch of the James Webb Space Telescope
is about as high stakes as it gets for NASA.
If something goes wrong, that is about ten billion dollars,
more than two decades' worth of work, down the drain, just like that.
[Thomas] Hey.
-[woman] How you doing? -Well.
[female reporter] Thomas Zurbuchen is the head of science at NASA,
translation.ko: 나사 과학부 부국장인 토머스 주부큰 씨는

translation.en: or Dr. Z, as we can also call you.
The day has come.
All these decades, all this time,
all these people working on this telescope,
translation.ko: 이 많은 사람이 이 망원경을 위해 일했고

translation.en: and here we are, minutes to launch.
translation.ko: 드디어 발사를 몇 분 앞두고 있는데요

translation.en: [Thomas] We have this telescope on top of this rocket.
A telescope that 10,000-plus people have worked on in many ways.
And together with that telescope,
all the hopes and dreams of those individuals,
translation.ko: 그 모든 이들에게는 희망과 꿈이 있었고

translation.en: and also tens of thousands of scientists, some of them not even born,
translation.ko: 과학자 수만 명과 이 데이터로 혜택을 누릴

translation.en: that will benefit from this data, are there with them,
translation.ko: 아직 태어나지도 않은 이들까지 다 함께

translation.en: waiting for these last minutes of countdown for its journey to-- to space.
translation.ko: 우주로 가는 여정의 마지막 카운트다운을 기다려요

translation.en: [engineer] Thumbs up, all systems are go.
T-minus 30 seconds and counting.
[Thomas] Webb, in the whole history of NASA, is the toughest mission ever done.
translation.ko: 웹 망원경은 나사 역사상 가장 힘든 임무예요

translation.en: There were manufacturing issues, planning issues, system issues,
translation.ko: 제조, 계획, 시스템에 문제가 있었고 "토머스 주부큰 나사 과학부 부국장"

translation.en: personnel issues.
Sometimes it looked hopeless to me.
translation.ko: 가망이 없는 것처럼 보일 때도 있었어요

translation.en: [engineer] Standing by for terminal count.
[man in French] Ten, nine, eight…
[Thomas in English] I've often thought of Webb as the Apollo of science.
translation.ko: 전 웹 망원경을 과학의 아폴로 프로그램이라고 생각했어요

translation.en: It is a super hard thing that's almost impossible.
And we do it despite it.
[man in French] …three, two, one, liftoff!
[Amber] It's been a really long road to get to this launch.
I've worked on the project for 15 years.
I feel like such a core part of my identity as a person
translation.ko: 한 개인으로서 제 정체성의 핵심이 "앰버 스트론 나사 천체 물리학자"

translation.en: is my-- my job, my work.
I love it, I'm passionate about it, that's why I do it.
translation.ko: 이 일을 사랑하고 열의를 쏟죠 그래서 하는 거예요

translation.en: To try to think the unthinkable of, "If it doesn't work,"
translation.ko: '실패하면 어쩌지'라는 생각할 수도 없는 일을 생각해요

translation.en: like, and then I've poured my entire career into this,
translation.ko: 이 일에 내 경력을 전부 걸기도 했죠

translation.en: it's a scary thought, for sure.
I mean, from the time I was six or seven,
I decided that that's what I want to do. I want to be an astronomer.
I grew up in rural Arkansas on a little farm, middle of nowhere.
translation.ko: 전 아칸소주 시골의 외딴 작은 농장에서 자랐어요

translation.en: There were no city lights around.
It was very dark. The sky was beautiful.
And I was just enthralled by the night sky from the time I was a kid.
I was in fourth or fifth grade, when Hubble launched.
[commander] We have been given the go-ahead to begin commanding
translation.ko: 진행해도 좋다고 합니다 전방 래치 해제 명령을 시작합니다

translation.en: a release of the forward latches.
We're seeing both blankets unfurl on the solar array.
translation.ko: 태양 전지판 위로 장막 두 개가 펼쳐지는 게 보이죠

translation.en: [engineer] Looks good.
I want to wish Hubble its own set of adventures,
that it may unlock further mysteries of the universe.
translation.ko: 우주의 신비를 더 밝혀 주길 바랍니다

translation.en: [Amber] They decided to point it at a blank piece of sky,
translation.ko: 아무것도 없는 텅 빈 하늘로 보내서

translation.en: nothing there, just to see what happened.
Like the rest of the world,
I remember just being stunned at what we saw.
translation.ko: 저 역시 눈앞에 펼쳐진 걸 보고 깜짝 놀랐어요

translation.en: The nothing turned out to be filled with thousands of galaxies.
translation.ko: 아무것도 없는 줄 알았는데 은하 수천 개로 가득했죠

translation.en: It really gave us a sense, for the very first time,
just how old the universe is.
It's a really cool, sort of, trick of physics…
[chuckles] …uh, that we can literally look back in time, uh,
with these massive telescopes.
Telescopes are really like time machines
in that they let us see the universe as it was in the past.
translation.ko: 우주의 과거 모습을 보여준다는 점에서 망원경은 정말 타임머신 같아요

translation.en: This sounds like science fiction,
but it's actually just due to the simple fact
translation.ko: 빛이 공간을 이동하는 데 시간이 걸린다는

translation.en: that light takes time to travel through space.
translation.ko: 빛이 공간을 이동하는 데 시간이 걸린다는 단순한 사실 때문이에요

translation.en: If you look at a streetlamp, the light from that streetlamp
translation.ko: 예를 들어 가로등을 보면 그 빛이 거리를 지나 우리 눈에 도달하기까지

translation.en: takes a teeny, tiny fraction of a second to cross the street and get to your eye.
translation.ko: 그 빛이 거리를 지나 우리 눈에 도달하기까지 찰나의 시간이 걸리거든요

translation.en: Light from the Sun takes about eight minutes to get to Earth.
translation.ko: 태양 빛은 지구까지 약 8분 만에 오고요

translation.en: Think about stepping that out further and further into the universe.
translation.ko: 그보다 더 먼 우주로 나간다고 생각해 보세요

translation.en: Things that are much further away,
the light takes more time to travel to our telescopes.
translation.ko: 그 빛이 망원경에 도달하기까지 더 오래 걸려요

translation.en: And so we are literally seeing them as they were in the past.
translation.ko: 그러니 말 그대로 과거에 있던 빛을 보는 거예요

translation.en: With Hubble, we've been able to look back into the distant past
translation.ko: 허블 망원경으로 "현대 은하 형성" 먼 과거를 볼 수 있게 됐어요

translation.en: and see some very early galaxies, some very young galaxies.
translation.ko: 생긴 지 얼마 안 된 은하나 초기 은하를 볼 수 있지만 "최초의 갤럭시 형성"

translation.en: But… we're missing the beginning.
We're missing the first bit in the first chapter
of this 13.8-billion-year story of the universe.
[Dan Goldin] We want to look out into the vastness of space
and back to the beginnings of time to answer the questions,
translation.ko: 태초의 시간으로 돌아가 이런 질문에 답하고 싶습니다 "댄 골딘 전 나사 국장"

translation.en: "How did, and how do, galaxies form?"
"Are there other habitable planets outside our solar system?"
translation.ko: '우리 태양계 외에도 생명체가 살 행성이 있는가?'

translation.en: "Is life unique to planet Earth?"
Hubble and ground-based telescopes have given us an important start.
translation.ko: 허블 망원경과 지상 망원경 덕분에 중요한 시작을 하게 됐습니다

translation.en: But we must go farther,
and the Next Generation Space Telescope,
NGST, will be the next great step taken.
translation.ko: NGST로 크게 한 걸음 나아가게 될 것입니다

translation.en: [Amber] That's what ended up being the James Webb Space Telescope.
translation.ko: 그게 결국 제임스 웹 우주 망원경이 되었죠

translation.en: [Thomas] Webb is such a leap.
It's the biggest leap of any mission, in terms of just the magnitude of improvements in all dimensions.
translation.ko: 모든 면에서 상당히 개선됐기에 그 어떤 임무보다 큰 발전이죠

translation.en: This is like the mother of all telescopes.
It was clear that there's ten miracles that needed to happen.
Entirely new technologies that nobody had ever done.
translation.ko: 그 누구도 해 본 적 없는 완전히 새로운 기술이었어요

translation.en: A totally new detector,
totally new electronic system that focused the mirrors,
translation.ko: 거울에 집중한 완전히 새로운 전자 시스템이

translation.en: ten of those.
One of the most important numbers is,
"How many single point failures do you have?"
A single point failure is a single thing that needs to happen
translation.ko: 단일 장애 지점이란 잘되어야 하는 한 부분인데

translation.en: that, if it's not happening, the whole mission is a failure.
translation.ko: 그게 안 되면 임무 전체가 실패하는 거예요

translation.en: [radio controller] Navigation confirmed that the parachute has deployed
translation.ko: 낙하산이 펼쳐진 것이 내비게이션으로 확인됩니다 "마스 퍼서비어런스 2021년"

translation.en: and we are seeing significant deceleration.
[Thomas] Landing on Mars is something like 80 to 90,
which is one of the riskiest things we've ever done.
Webb is three to four times worse.
translation.ko: 웹 망원경은 그보다 서너 배 더 심해요

translation.en: [astronaut] Oh, it's beautiful, Mike, it really is.
They've got the flag up now, and you can see the stars and stripes.
translation.ko: 이제 성조기를 꽂았습니다 무늬가 잘 보이는군요 "아폴로 11 1969년"

translation.en: [Thomas] In terms of the single point failures, worse than Apollo.
translation.ko: 단일 장애 지점 관련해서는 아폴로보다 심해요

translation.en: So, how many single point failures do we have?
translation.ko: "단일 장애 지점" 단일 장애 지점이 몇 개일까요?

translation.en: The answer is 344.
It's the largest number of single point failures
of any mission ever done.
It's like, you know, just an impossible project.
[Mike] There's always unknown unknowns in this business, we know it.
translation.ko: 이 분야에선 예상치 못한 부분이 늘 나오기 마련이고 우리도 알아요

translation.en: In the end, you know, technically, it will all fall on my shoulders.
translation.ko: 결국 엄밀히 말하면 전부 제가 짊어져야 해요

translation.en: You just make the best decision you can with the data that you have available,
translation.ko: 현재 있는 데이터를 바탕으로 최선의 결정을 내려야 하지만

translation.en: but you recognize that… there's always a bit of risk to some of these decisions.
translation.ko: 이런 결정에는 항상 위험 부담이 따른다는 걸 알아야겠죠

translation.en: -[Mike] Cat? -[Cathy Menzel] Yeah.
Oh, lighten-- lighten up, killer.
[Mike] For the past 24 years, I've been focused on this mission.
It's like a, you know, a second child in a-- in a way.
My children have known nothing but the James Webb Space Telescope
translation.ko: 우리 애들은 제임스 웹 우주 망원경밖에 몰랐죠

translation.en: since they were about nine or four.
translation.ko: 아홉 살 혹은 네 살 때부터요

translation.en: My son is 30 now, and my daughter's 28.
The fear that-- that you have to have is, if something goes wrong,
there's going to be the press, there's going to be the, you know, the politicians, whatever.
translation.ko: 언론이나 정치인 등이 뭐라고 할 거라는 부분이에요

translation.en: They're gonna drag your name through the mud.
He worries about everything. It's a-- It's a Menzel gene, actually.
translation.ko: 이이는 전부 걱정해요 멘젤 가문 유전자가 그래요 "캐시 멘젤 마이크의 아내"

translation.en: They worry about every little thing.
He's not sleeping well at night.
All these single point failure things that could go wrong,
translation.ko: 잘못될 수도 있는 온갖 단일 장애 지점 때문에

translation.en: you do worry about those, and, you know…
[Mike] Damn right, I do. Damn right, the team does, so…
translation.ko: 당연히 걱정하죠 나도 팀원들도 다들 걱정해요

translation.en: That's why we put vigilance on 'em, we put focus on 'em.
translation.ko: 그래서 경계를 늦추지 않고 늘 주목하는 거죠

translation.en: These are some of the original concepts
on, uh, what was then called the Next Generation Space Telescope.
The bigger the mirror, the more light you're collecting.
translation.ko: 거울이 클수록 빛도 더 많이 모을 수 있어요 "주경 배치 타워"

translation.en: So, to actually see first light, you're going to have to be big.
We had five-- five concepts that we looked at. This was, uh, an original one.
The devil in these designs are in the details,
so it isn't until you get to, you know, some detailed engineering
that looks like this, that you find the problems.
The most obvious problem,
its-- its diameter is bigger than the diameter of the rocket that carries it.
translation.ko: 이걸 운반하는 로켓보다 지름이 더 컸다는 점이에요

translation.en: So you have to fold it up.
We had deployments that had the primary mirror segments stacked,
almost like a record player.
And then one of the concepts that we had was, uh, to deploy the primary mirror
translation.ko: 주경을 배치할 때 양쪽 끝이 "+J2 방향에서 본 측면 배치 형태"

translation.en: using two leaves that look like a drop table,
which is what we're doing now.
Our preliminary design review was 2008,
and that's where the telescope starts really looking like what we have today.
It's not one of the best models of Webb,
translation.ko: 웹 망원경 모델 중 최고는 아니지만

translation.en: but it's good enough to show most people the features.
translation.ko: 대다수 사람에게 기능을 보여줄 정도는 됐어요

translation.en: There's the primary mirror. Starlight comes in,
hits the primary mirror, gets focused down to the secondary mirror,
and gets sent into this, uh, black pyramidal structure.
translation.ko: 이 검정 피라미드형 구조물로 보내진 다음

translation.en: After that, it goes back here where the instruments are.
The cameras, the spectrometers…
I'm sorry, the-- the glue is coming a little loose on this,
but this right here is the sunshield.
The sunshield blocks out the light from the Sun, the Earth, and the Moon.
translation.ko: 태양 차단막은 태양과 지구 그리고 달의 빛을 막아 줘요

translation.en: We want our telescope to be cold,
so that it doesn't glow brighter than the faint stars it's looking at.
translation.ko: 관찰 중인 희미한 별보다 더 밝게 빛나면 안 되니까요

translation.en: Of the 344 single point failure items,
225 are associated with the sunshield deployment.
translation.ko: 이 태양 차단막 배치와 관련돼 있어요 "단일 장애 지점 225개"

translation.en: That is a never-before-done deployment.
translation.ko: 이런 배치는 지금껏 한 번도 해 본 적 없어요

translation.en: The first thing that happens,
those two big pallets that you see on each side,
fold down one, then fold down the other.
translation.ko: 한쪽을 내린 다음 다른 한쪽도 내려요

translation.en: They're holding the folded layers of the sunshield.
translation.ko: 그 안에 접힌 태양 차단막이 여러 겹으로 들어가 있죠

translation.en: Then a very complex system of pulleys and tensioning motors
translation.ko: 팽팽하게 당기는 모터와 도르래로 된 복잡한 시스템으로

translation.en: expand the sunshield at each of the six vertices.
translation.ko: 각 꼭짓점 여섯 개에서 태양 차단막을 펼쳐요

translation.en: And we will individually tension each of those five layers
translation.ko: 그다음 다섯 겹 각각을 팽팽하게 당겨서

translation.en: to get not only the right shape, but the right position, relative to each other.
translation.ko: 모양뿐 아니라 상대적인 위치도 정확히 잡죠

translation.en: There are 34 single point failure items
associated with the tensioning of the five layers.
[radio controller] Layer two, on three, two, one…
[Thomas] The thing that's really different from this space mission
to pretty much any other space mission ever done, is how flimsy it is.
translation.ko: 다른 부분이 있다면 잘 찢어진다는 점이에요

translation.en: It's not a piece of metal.
It's more like a folded-up umbrella.
[Mike] We did three full-scale deployments,
translation.ko: 실제 척도로 세 번을 펼쳐 봤는데

translation.en: and the refolding put wear and tear on the sunshield.
translation.ko: 다시 접는 작업에서 태양 차단막이 찢어지고 훼손됐죠

translation.en: The tearing of the sunshield that we were seeing
translation.ko: 태양 차단막이 찢어졌을 때 다들 생각했어요

translation.en: got to the point where we said, "No."
translation.ko: 태양 차단막이 찢어졌을 때 다들 생각했어요 '안 되겠다, 너무 지나치게 시험하는 건 그만하자'

translation.en: "It's time to stop testing and overtesting."
translation.ko: '안 되겠다, 너무 지나치게 시험하는 건 그만하자'

translation.en: When you're doing things like, you know, large sheets,
it's miles of cables, things that can get tangled,
translation.ko: 몇 킬로미터 되는 케이블을 쓰니 여기저기 꼬일 수도 있고

translation.en: can go in places you don't want them to in zero-G.
translation.ko: 무중력 상태에서는 가선 안 될 곳에 들어가기도 해요

translation.en: You can think of a thousand things that can go wrong.
We bust it up, fold it up, we're going to put it on a rocket,
and then we're going to literally rebuild it robotically in space,
translation.ko: 우주에 올라가서 로봇으로 다시 만드는 거예요

translation.en: and that's, uh-- that's never been done before.
Fourteen days after launch, we latch both sides of the primary mirror.
There are ten single point failure items associated with the primary mirror,
five for each wing.
Having 18 individual segments was a good way to build the mirror.
translation.ko: 18개 조각으로 나눈 것은 거울을 만드는 좋은 방법이었어요

translation.en: Each individual mirror's movable.
That helps us to position each of those hexagons
translation.ko: 각 6각형의 자리를 잡아서 로봇으로 망원경의 초점을 맞추는 데 도움이 돼요

translation.en: to robotically focus our telescope.
translation.ko: 로봇으로 망원경의 초점을 맞추는 데 도움이 돼요

translation.en: It's going out about a million miles away from the Earth,
translation.ko: 지구에서 약 160만 킬로미터 떨어진 곳으로 갈 거예요

translation.en: four times farther than the Moon.
You don't want the telescope cracking, breaking,
translation.ko: 극저온으로 떨어질 때 망원경에 금이 가고 깨지면 곤란하잖아요

translation.en: when it gets down to cryogenic temperatures.
[Amber] NASA actually retrofitted
the biggest Cryovac chamber down at Johnson Space Center.
translation.ko: 존슨 우주 센터에 있는 가장 큰 진공실을 보강했어요

translation.en: It was used for Apollo era.
It took years to be able to accommodate this huge telescope.
translation.ko: 이 거대한 망원경을 수용하기까지 몇 년이 걸렸어요

translation.en: [Mike chuckling] It's the size of a three-story building,
tested at temperatures, you know, at 50 degrees above absolute zero, and it worked great.
That's almost miraculous.
[Amber chuckling] There was this awesome day at Goddard
that people have been looking forward to for years, really.
They raised it upright and rotated it towards the viewing area,
translation.ko: 거울을 세로로 세운 다음 관람실 쪽으로 돌려서

translation.en: and we all got to see that mirror.
translation.ko: 다들 그 거울을 볼 수 있게 됐거든요

translation.en: And that was just a, like, "Whew, don't start crying" moment.
translation.ko: 다들 눈물 나는 걸 겨우 참은 순간이었어요

translation.en: I mean, because you're-- you're seeing your own reflection
in the same mirror that's going to detect light
from infant galaxies and distant planets.
And to think that it's also seeing me? Like, that was-- that was really cool.
translation.ko: 그게 나를 비춰 주다니 정말 멋진 경험이었어요

translation.en: We've designed this telescope
specifically to see the universe in infrared light.
translation.ko: 적외선으로 우주를 볼 수 있게 설계됐어요

translation.en: The most distant galaxies are so far away
translation.ko: 가장 먼 곳의 은하는 너무 멀어서

translation.en: that they are emitting all of their light as infrared light,
light that's a little bit more red than what your eyes can see.
translation.ko: 사람의 눈에 보이는 것보다 붉은빛이 더 많아요

translation.en: Even if we had a telescope like Hubble, a visible-light telescope,
that was much, much, much bigger,
we still wouldn't be able to see the light from these first galaxies.
translation.ko: 최초의 은하에서 나오는 빛을 관찰하진 못할 거예요

translation.en: While we designed this telescope to primarily study early galaxies,
translation.ko: 이 망원경은 주로 초기 은하를 연구하기 위해 설계됐지만

translation.en: the fact that it's so big and so powerful
means that it will have unprecedented capability
in helping us learn more about exoplanets, about planets orbiting other stars.
translation.ko: 외계 행성, 즉 다른 별 주위를 도는 행성을 연구하는 데 도움이 될 거예요

translation.en: In particular, about whether or not any of the nearby planets
translation.ko: 특히 근처 행성 중에 어떤 곳에라도

translation.en: might be potentially habitable.
translation.ko: 생명체가 살 수 있는지 알아볼 수 있겠죠

translation.en: The way it will do that
translation.ko: 그건 그 행성의 대기에 있는 분자를

translation.en: is by looking at the molecules that are in that planet's atmosphere.
translation.ko: 그건 그 행성의 대기에 있는 분자를 분석해 보면 알 수 있어요

translation.en: It would be able to detect methane, carbon dioxide, water vapor.
translation.ko: 메탄, 이산화탄소, 수증기를 감지할 수 있겠죠

translation.en: Where there's water, there's usually life.
translation.ko: 보통 물이 있는 곳에는 생명체가 있어요

translation.en: It's not a stretch to say that this telescope
translation.ko: 이 망원경이 생명 탐사에서 아주 큰 도약이 될 거라고 해도

translation.en: is our next, sort of, giant leap in our search for life in the universe.
translation.ko: 이 망원경이 생명 탐사에서 아주 큰 도약이 될 거라고 해도 과언이 아니에요

translation.en: I mean, how amazing would it be if I said, "Look, here are five planets,
translation.ko: 이렇게 말하면 얼마나 근사하겠어요? '이 다섯 행성에 생명체가 사는 것 같아요'

translation.en: it looks like there is life there"?
translation.ko: '이 다섯 행성에 생명체가 사는 것 같아요'

translation.en: Can you imagine? That changes everything.
translation.ko: 상상이 가세요? 판도가 완전히 바뀌는 거죠

translation.en: Webb is humans at its best,
a selfless pursuit of what's really out there.
translation.ko: 우주에 무엇이 있는지 이타적으로 좇는 거죠

translation.en: Learning more about ourselves, our history, about the world itself.
translation.ko: 우리 자신, 역사, 세계 자체를 더 알아 가는 거예요

translation.en: I think it's incredibly amazing.
I grew up in Switzerland.
My father was an evangelist pastor in a fundamentalist church.
We hardly ever heard about science.
translation.ko: 우린 과학에 관해서 들어본 적이 거의 없었죠

translation.en: I was taught all my youth
that the whole universe was built in seven days.
And then I went to one class.
The teacher explained how science changed the trajectory of history.
translation.ko: 선생님이 과학이 역사의 궤도를 어떻게 바꿨는지 설명해 주셨어요

translation.en: And I thought, "That's the job I want."
"I can do science, and through it, change the course of history."
translation.ko: 나도 과학을 해서 역사의 궤도를 바꾸겠다고 생각했죠

translation.en: I've been in the job for five years.
Many people think of me as not patient enough.
My way of accountability sometimes can come across as harsh.
translation.ko: 가혹할 정도로 책임감을 요구할 때도 있어요

translation.en: But suppose it failed.
It would set the whole history of world science back
by one to two decades.
I track all my miles.
The whole year… A thousand is the goal every year.
Depending on how stressful the year is, it's more or less. The more stress, the more miles.
translation.ko: 1년 동안 스트레스 정도에 따라 스트레스가 많으면 더 달려요

translation.en: Closing in on 1,200.
NASA, right? This is the agency that has coined the… the tagline,
translation.ko: 나사가 만든 슬로건에는 이런 것도 있어요

translation.en: ''Failure is not an option.''
It's a tagline that sounds really good,
but every time we do a mission, failure is an option.
translation.ko: 우리가 임무를 할 때마다 늘 실패 가능성이 있어요

translation.en: There are all these challenges from the very beginning.
This institute will be managing a telescope
with a launch projected for 2007.
The target price for doing this will be 500 million dollars.
[Thomas] The first time somebody talked about the price of that telescope,
translation.ko: 처음에 누군가가 그 망원경의 가격을 얘기했을 때

translation.en: everybody who had-- had worked on-- on the Hubble Space Telescope,
translation.ko: 허블 우주 망원경은 60억 달러 이상 들었으니

translation.en: which was close-- more than six billion dollars,
knew it's total bullshit.
As the project grew,
all of a sudden, the cost went to six billion dollars.
Mr. Howard, did you ever see the movie called The Money Pit?
translation.ko: 하워드 씨, 혹시 '머니 핏'이라는 영화를 보셨나요?

translation.en: [Howard] Yes, absolutely.
I think the standard line in that movie was, ''It's only two more weeks.''
translation.ko: 그 영화 속 유명한 대사는 '2주만 더 주세요'일 거예요

translation.en: Mm-hmm. Now, how can we justify this to our constituents?
[Thomas] There was an investigation by Congress.
And they basically said, "Let's kill that thing."
It felt like it wasn't going to happen.
Congress was going to cancel us.
It was a shock.
I'm a-- a young scientist anxious to do science with this telescope,
translation.ko: 전 이 망원경으로 과학을 하려고 안달 난 젊은 과학자였는데

translation.en: and now we're stopping after all this time?
[Thomas] Congress said, "We'll give you the money," and that's when I came in.
translation.ko: 의회가 돈을 주겠다고 했고 그때 내가 투입됐어요

translation.en: Nobody wanted to talk about it. It's like, "Oh, it's-- it's not-- it's fine."
translation.ko: 그 얘기는 다들 꺼렸어요 '아, 뭐… 괜찮아요'

translation.en: It's like, "Well, how are you performing?" "We're losing time, but it will be fine."
It was not fine.
I remember it getting ready for vibration and acoustics.
[Thomas] What you do is you try to break the telescope.
Of course you want it to survive, but you shake it
translation.ko: 물론 안 부서지길 바라지만 로켓에 넣었을 때처럼 마구 흔들어요

translation.en: just like it will be shaken in the rocket.
And we blasted sound at it, just like it will see during a launch.
translation.ko: 그리고 발사 때 보는 것처럼 굉음도 냈어요

translation.en: [Thomas] The first test went really, really well.
Then, when we tested it with the spacecraft and the sunshield,
translation.ko: 그다음 우주선과 태양 차단막에 대고 시험했는데

translation.en: the fasteners started falling down.
There's 10,000 screws on that thing.
Now, if you've ever fixed a bicycle,
you realize if you put the fastener on, you need to tighten it, so it locks.
translation.ko: 나사를 넣고 고정될 때까지 꽉 조여야 하잖아요

translation.en: The fasteners were not locked.
translation.ko: 근데 나사가 꽉 안 잠긴 거죠

translation.en: How can that be?
It needs to go to space. The fasteners need to be locked.
So we had to redo all the fasteners, find all of them.
translation.ko: 그래서 나사를 전부 다 찾아서 전부 다시 했어요

translation.en: It took six months
and cost 150 million dollars to fix the problem.
Frankly, people are making more mistakes than they should.
translation.ko: 솔직히 해선 안 되는 실수를 하고 있어요

translation.en: It's embarrassing.
In the meantime, we got the largest number of negative news stories
translation.ko: 그와 동시에 이 임무에 관한 부정적인 기사가 "오래 지연된 값비싼 망원경"

translation.en: of that mission, as compared to any and all of them.
translation.ko: 이전과는 비교도 못 하게 많이 쏟아졌어요 "나사의 실력이 무뎌졌다는 보고"

translation.en: Nobody wants to be part of a stinker.
Everybody wants to be part of a success, just like any sports team.
translation.ko: 여느 스포츠처럼 다들 성공하고 싶어 하죠

translation.en: You need to turn it around. You need to stop losing.
translation.ko: 방향을 바꿔서 실패를 멈춰야 해요 "뒤처질 위기에 처한 웹"

translation.en: The team, they were always amazing people.
I consider it a leadership issue.
We run the risk of scratching and damaging the mirror,
so we have to be very careful about that.
[Thomas] What I needed to do is replace leaders to bring that team together
translation.ko: 저는 리더들을 교체해서 팀이 뭉치도록 돕고

translation.en: and create the attention that it requires to do something this magnificent.
translation.ko: 이렇게 대단한 일을 할 때 꼭 필요한 주의력을 만들어야 했죠

translation.en: Right, so you want the energy, "Yes, we're going to do this."
translation.ko: '그래, 우린 해낼 수 있어' 이런 에너지가 필요해요

translation.en: And then I think that's what happened.
I remember the day where I basically…
For the first time, I was really surprised.
The two halves,
translation.ko: 두 부분으로 나뉘어 있는 주경과 태양 차단막을

translation.en: the primary mirror and the sunshield, they had to come together.
translation.ko: 두 부분으로 나뉘어 있는 주경과 태양 차단막을 합쳐야 하거든요

translation.en: I knew that was going to be really hard.
They had never seen each other, those two halves.
translation.ko: 이 둘은 한자리에 있어 본 적이 없거든요

translation.en: All the systems, all the cables, everything had to work.
translation.ko: 모든 시스템, 케이블 등이 전부 다 잘 작동해야 해요

translation.en: When the two halves came together…
it worked the first time.
The team were just barely where they needed to be,
translation.ko: 팀원들은 원래 겨우 할 일을 하는 정도였고

translation.en: and they were not ahead, and all of sudden, they got ahead.
translation.ko: 앞서진 못했는데 갑자기 앞지르게 된 거예요

translation.en: They were better than what people had expected them to be.
That is amazing.
We have a mission that's basically ready.
If somebody asks me, "How certain are you to launch Webb right now?"
translation.ko: 누가 웹을 발사할 가능성을 얼마나 확신하느냐고 묻는다면

translation.en: I'm betting my house.
[Amber] All of these years we've put into getting this telescope
translation.ko: 이 망원경을 발사대에 갖다 놓는 데까지

translation.en: to the launchpad.
Part of me is like, "Is it really here? Is it really happening?" [laughs]
I feel excitement and-- and, uh, happy nervousness.
[Mike] Do I like launches? Well…
[chuckling] I like-- I like them when they're over.
It's like jumping with a parachute, right?
[chuckling] When the parachute opens, it's always a nice-- a nice ride.
translation.ko: 일단 낙하산이 펼쳐지면 늘 기분 좋게 타잖아요

translation.en: We are just about 12 hours from launching. Fingers crossed that the weather holds,
translation.ko: 발사까지 고작 12시간 남았어요 날씨가 좋길 바라요

translation.en: and we'll be able to launch this telescope tomorrow morning.
translation.ko: 그러면 내일 아침 망원경을 발사할 수 있어요

translation.en: I can't believe… I can't believe that we're almost here.
translation.ko: 거의 다 오다니 정말 믿기지 않아요

translation.en: I'm so excited. I can't wait to get this telescope into space.
translation.ko: 정말 기대돼요, 이 망원경을 얼른 우주로 보내고 싶어요

translation.en: [Thomas] I write both speeches by myself.
translation.ko: 두 연설문을 전부 제가 직접 작성해요

translation.en: I think it's absolutely critical that they're authentic and personal,
translation.ko: 진정성 있고 개인적인 얘기를 쓰는 게 정말 중요해요

translation.en: uh, especially in a time of disappointment,
frankly,
that I'm there authentically as a human.
translation.ko: 한 인간으로서 진정성 있게 왔다는 걸 보여야죠

translation.en: So that's important.
The positive speech, nobody will remember.
translation.ko: 긍정적인 결과에 대한 연설문은 아무도 기억 못 할 거예요

translation.en: It won't matter. I can say whatever I want to.
translation.ko: 연설은 상관없을 거고 마음대로 말해도 돼요

translation.en: The negative speech really matters.
translation.ko: 부정적인 결과에 대한 연설문이 진짜 중요해요

translation.en: So, it's really important to think about it carefully.
[man in French] Seven, six, five,
four, three, two, one, liftoff.
Ignition.
[Thomas in English] I remember the first Ariane 5 failure. I still remember how it looked.
translation.ko: 아리안 5호의 첫 실패가 기억나요 그 모습이 아직도 기억나요

translation.en: [man in French] Liftoff.
[Thomas in English] I still remember it, burned in my-- in my head.
[man in French] All propulsion parameters are normal. Trajectory is normal.
[Thomas in English] "Today's launch was not successful,
and Webb did not reach the orbit as planned."
"This is a setback for all of us,
and for science and exploration of our universe."
"We surely are disappointed."
"However, as difficult as the setback we're experiencing right now is,
translation.ko: '하지만 지금 우리가 경험한 이 차질이 힘든 만큼'

translation.en: there's one thing that will not change."
"Our commitment to the scientific exploration of space."
[woman 1] The coolest thing of the decade, possibly the century, is about to happen.
translation.ko: 10년, 어쩌면 한 세기 중에서 가장 멋진 일이 생길 거예요

translation.en: The successor to the Hubble,
three times as large and way more technologically advanced,
translation.ko: 허블보다 3배 더 크고 기술적으로 훨씬 진보한 망원경이

translation.en: is about to be launched. I'm going to start crying.
translation.ko: 곧 발사하게 될 거예요 눈물 날 것 같아요

translation.en: [woman 2] Feliz Navidad. I got up at 4:50 a.m. this morning
translation.ko: '메리 크리스마스' 제임스 웹 우주 망원경의 발사를 보려고

translation.en: to watch the JWST launch.
[man] Just praying to all the science gods that everything goes without a hitch,
translation.ko: 아무 문제 없이 전부 다 잘되고 6개월 후에 멋진 데이터가 나오길

translation.en: and that in six months, we'll be able to get this wonderful data.
Merry Christmas, everyone.
[controller] From the Jupiter Control Center here in Kourou, French Guiana,
translation.ko: 프랑스령 기아나의 쿠루에 있는 이곳 주피터 컨트롤 센터에서

translation.en: you are looking live at an Ariane 5 rocket on its launchpad,
translation.ko: 발사대에 있는 아리안 5호 로켓을 실시간으로 보고 계십니다

translation.en: ready to send the James Webb Space Telescope
translation.ko: 제임스 웹 우주 망원경을 발사할 준비가 되었죠

translation.en: on the initial phase of its journey.
translation.ko: 이 여정의 첫 단계를 시작하게 됩니다

translation.en: [Thomas] Tens of thousands of scientists are watching this launch right now.
translation.ko: 지금 과학자 수만 명이 이 발사를 보고 있어요

translation.en: Their entire future depends on the success of that launch.
translation.ko: "후지모토 세이지 천체 물리학자" 이들의 미래가 발사의 성공 여부에 달려 있죠 "사우라브 자"

translation.en: Merry Christmas!
We're here and ready to watch the James Webb Space Telescope launch.
translation.ko: 제임스 웹 우주 망원경의 발사를 볼 건데요 "댄 코 천체 물리학자"

translation.en: [controller] Right now, we have a green board,
translation.ko: "킬런 윌콤 천체 물리학자" 초록 불이 들어왔고요 이상 없이 카운트다운 진행됩니다

translation.en: no issues as the countdown proceeds.
translation.ko: 초록 불이 들어왔고요 이상 없이 카운트다운 진행됩니다 "양 야오룬 천체 물리학자"

translation.en: No issues again being tracked by the flight control team here in Kourou.
translation.ko: "피터 에이브러햄 천체 물리학자" 이곳 쿠루의 비행 제어 팀도 추적 결과 이상이 없다고 합니다 "하리카네 유이치 천체 물리학자"

translation.en: I'm not a very superstitious man,
but I am going to take three, uh-- three lucky charms with me today.
translation.ko: 오늘 행운의 부적을 세 개 가져갈 거예요

translation.en: I have my old man's taxi license.
I have my grandfather Menzel's bow tie
and my grandfather DeLeo's logbook from his, uh-- when he was a private pilot.
translation.ko: 우리 들리오 할아버지의 자가용 조종사 시절 항해 일지죠

translation.en: [female reporter] It's all looking very good here at the spaceport
translation.ko: 성탄절 발사를 앞두고 이곳 우주 기지는 전부 좋아 보입니다

translation.en: for a Christmas Day launch.
translation.ko: 이곳 우주 기지는 전부 좋아 보입니다

translation.en: Operations running smoothly, the countdown ticking over nicely,
all the systems are green, and we are go for launch.
translation.ko: "토머스 메기스 천체 물리학자" 모든 시스템에 이상이 없고 예정대로 발사를 진행합니다

translation.en: [male reporter] The weather is go.
NASA officials carefully, uh, watching, uh, the telemetry,
standing by for terminal count.
[man in French] Ten, nine, eight…
[in English] Seven, six, five,
four, three, two, one…
[man in French] ESC shutdown.
All onboard parameters are normal.
[male reporter in English] And we're about 17 seconds away from Webb separation.
Springs will gently push Webb away from the upper stage of the Ariane 5.
translation.ko: 용수철이 아리안 5의 상부에서 웹을 부드럽게 밀어낼 겁니다

translation.en: [man in French] Separation of the Webb Telescope.
-[in English] Go, Webb! -[applause]
-Thank you. Yes! -[Thomas] Congratulations, eh? My gosh.
[male reporter] We do have confirmation of observatory separation,
that will lead, uh, to the deployment of Webb's solar array.
translation.ko: 이제 웹 망원경의 태양 전지판이 배치될 겁니다

translation.en: Webb will remain on internal battery power until its singular solar array unfurls.
translation.ko: 단일 태양 전지판을 펼칠 때까지 웹은 내부 배터리 전력을 사용하게 됩니다

translation.en: [male reporter] Webb now, uh, has its array out, confirmation that it is power positive.
translation.ko: 웹에서 전지판이 나왔고 전력이 있다고 확인됐습니다

translation.en: -[engineer] Solar array is out. -[applause]
[laughing] All right! All right!
[engineer laughing] Now we're talking!
[reporter 1] As it moves to its workplace about a million miles away from Earth,
translation.ko: 지구에서 약 160만 킬로미터 떨어진 곳으로 작업실을 옮기면서

translation.en: it will be deployed by the telescope controllers
translation.ko: 임무 운영 센터 일명 MOC에 있는 제어 장치로

translation.en: at the Mission Operations Center, the MOC, as it's called.
[reporter 2] Over the next few weeks, Webb will continue deploying
translation.ko: "비행 통제실" 웹 망원경은 앞으로 몇 주 동안

translation.en: its antennas, sunshield, and mirrors.
translation.ko: 안테나, 태양 차단막, 거울들을 계속 배치할 겁니다

translation.en: Each procedure, a critical and complicated step
to fully assemble the seven-ton telescope.
translation.ko: 중요하고 복잡한 절차를 하나씩 밟게 됩니다

translation.en: [reporter 3] The Webb Telescope is created by some of the brightest minds in the world,
translation.ko: 웹 망원경은 전 세계에서 손꼽히게 똑똑한 이들이 만들었죠

translation.en: and all of them are gonna be watching at the edge of their seat.
translation.ko: 다들 손에 땀을 쥐며 지켜보고 있을 텐데요

translation.en: [reporter 4] Anything goes wrong at any point,
there's basically nothing humankind can actually do about it.
translation.ko: 인간이 어떻게 할 수 있는 일이 아니에요

translation.en: [Mike] Everybody's congratulating people here about the launch,
and we're all-- we're all very happy for the congratulations.
But we all know that, you know, the hard stuff is yet to come.
translation.ko: 앞으로 넘어야 할 산이 있다는 걸 다들 알아요

translation.en: Deploying this telescope is like rebuilding an IKEA desk
translation.ko: 이 망원경을 배치하는 건 160만 킬로미터 떨어진 곳에서

translation.en: from a million miles away, robotically.
translation.ko: 로봇으로 이케아 책상을 조립하는 것과 같아요

translation.en: Webb's going about a mile a second.
We'll be passing lunar orbit pretty soon,
so we're close to 230,000 miles away from us right now.
Webb is traveling to the L2 point,
a million miles away from the Earth.
If you're here on the Earth and want to see faint stars,
you don't look at them from the city, you go out to the country.
translation.ko: 도시가 아니라 시골에 가서 봐야 하잖아요

translation.en: So going out to L2, for us, represents going out to the country.
translation.ko: L2로 가는 건 시골에 가는 것과 같아요

translation.en: And it's a place where the gravity of the Sun and the gravity of the Earth can combine
to form a stable orbit around the Sun.
translation.ko: 태양 주위를 도는 안정적인 궤도를 만들 수 있는 곳이죠

translation.en: It took the Apollo astronauts roughly three days
translation.ko: 아폴로 우주 비행사들이 지구에서 달까지 가는 데

translation.en: to go from the Earth to the Moon.
To get out to the L2 point, it takes us about 30 days.
translation.ko: 우리가 L2 지점까지 가는 데는 약 30일이 걸려요

translation.en: And on its way out there, we're deploying.
[Scarlin Hernandez] This is my first deployment. I feel nervous.
Especially with this mission. It can't be serviced, right?
translation.ko: 특히 이번 임무에서는 수리할 수가 없잖아요

translation.en: So any problems that arise, any challenges,
translation.ko: 그러니 어떤 문제가 생기더라도 정면으로 맞서야 해요

translation.en: we have to take them head-on.
There are hundreds of us working, uh,
in the Mission Operations Center around the clock,
especially the flight operations team.
We're able to communicate with the telescope
via this Mission Operations Center.
We send commands to the telescope, or blocks of code,
to tell it what to do, what activity to perform.
translation.ko: 어떻게 할지, 어떤 수행을 할지 알려줄 수 있죠

translation.en: We can't actually see the telescope in space, it's too far,
translation.ko: "속도, 지구" 우주에 있는 이 망원경은 너무 멀어서 실제로는 못 봐요

translation.en: so we have a tool that's an animated model of the telescope,
translation.ko: 그래서 망원경을 애니메이션화한 모형으로 만드는 도구를 써요

translation.en: where we can see the telescope unfolding.
translation.ko: "관측대 시각화 도구" 그걸로 망원경이 펼쳐지는 걸 볼 수 있어요

translation.en: As a woman, being Latina,
it makes me a unicorn in this industry.
And I didn't have anyone like me to look up to in this space.
translation.ko: 여기에서 우러러보는 사람 중에 저처럼 생긴 사람은 없었죠

translation.en: I got my NASA badge when I was 19 years old.
I didn't expect to get there that fast, to such a big and prestigious place.
translation.ko: 이렇게 크고 명망 있는 곳에 그렇게 빨리 도달할 줄은 몰랐죠

translation.en: But as soon as I got there, I knew I was going to make my mark.
translation.ko: 하지만 여기 오자마자 유명해질 거라는 걸 알았어요

translation.en: I develop code and procedures for the deployment system.
translation.ko: 전 배치 시스템을 위한 코드와 절차를 개발해요

translation.en: No matter what activity we're performing on orbit,
all of those systems combined have to function and flow as one.
translation.ko: 그 모든 시스템을 통합해서 하나로 작동하고 흘러가야 해요

translation.en: [controller 1] Dep OC, that CR is pulled up. You have first command during the window.
translation.ko: 운영 부팀장님, CR이 멈췄습니다 이 시간 동안 첫 명령을 하십시오

translation.en: [engineer 1] Proceed. We are good to go.
[engineer 2] Copy that. Code execute.
[controller 2] The command line looks good. You're a go to execute.
translation.ko: 명령 라인 좋아 보입니다 실행해도 좋습니다

translation.en: [Scarlin] Execute.
[Mike] Most of the single point failures reside in the sunshield.
translation.ko: 단일 장애 지점 대부분이 태양 차단막 안에 있어요

translation.en: -If these mechanisms don't release… -[mechanism releasing] …that's a bad day.
translation.ko: 이 메커니즘이 작동을 안 하면 아주 곤란해져요

translation.en: [controller 2] Okay, Dep Lead, your motor has moved to the hold state.
translation.ko: 좋아요, 차장님 모터가 보류 상태로 들어갔습니다

translation.en: -And you're go to continue. -[Scarlin] Executing.
[controller 2] Copy that, boss. I am happy with that move.
translation.ko: 알겠습니다 그렇게 해도 좋을 것 같습니다

translation.en: Continue.
[Mike] No matter how many tests you do, just like a parachute,
translation.ko: 아무리 시험을 많이 해봤자 낙하산과 같아서

translation.en: it's only going to be as good as the last time you fold it.
translation.ko: 마지막에 접어 넣은 상태 그대로일 뿐이에요

translation.en: And you're never gonna know how good that is
until you jump out of the plane and pull the rip cord.
translation.ko: 줄을 당기기 전까지는 결과를 알 수 없죠

translation.en: [controller 3] Go to proceed onto step 031 for the group six.
[controller 2] Copy. On the wing.
[controller 3] And OC, that looks good. You are go to continue.
translation.ko: 운영 팀장님, 좋은 것 같습니다 계속해도 좋습니다

translation.en: [controller 2] Good to go. Proceed. Go ahead and continue with a go.
Proc looks good. You're go to execute.
[Scarlin] Executing.
[controller 1] You are go to fire.
[controller 2] Good to go. Let's see how they both fire.
And OC, you are go to execute deploy.
[Scarlin] Execute.
[controller 4] I can confirm that all five layers of the sunshield are fully tensioned.
translation.ko: 태양 차단막 다섯 겹이 모두 완전히 팽팽하게 펼쳐졌습니다

translation.en: [man] All right!
Thank you, Dep Lead.
Significant milestone accomplished. Job well done, sunshield team.
translation.ko: 중요한 마일스톤을 달성했습니다 수고했습니다, 태양 차단막 팀

translation.en: Job well done.
[Mike] All right, congratulations, everybody. Congratulations.
It was a good day. You know, it was hard-- hard to predict, and there it is.
Cooling the telescope, just the way it should.
translation.ko: 망원경을 식히는 중이에요 원래 상태로 돌려야죠

translation.en: It is a beautiful thing.
As of right now, we, uh-- we have eliminated 266
of the 344 single point failures.
They can't fail because they're no longer needed, they worked.
translation.ko: 이제 더는 필요하지 않으니 실패도 없죠, 성공적이었어요

translation.en: But you got to maintain the sense of caution,
because there's still some stuff to go.
-[man] Morning, Thomas. -Hey, everybody.
-[man] Morning. -[woman] Good morning.
[Thomas] Good to see you.
[controller 1] Stations at Madrid are green and standing by for handover.
translation.ko: 마드리드 기지에서 허가 떨어졌고 인계를 기다리는 중입니다

translation.en: [controller 2] And OC, Dep Ops on ops.
translation.ko: 운영 팀장님 운영 부장님이 수행 중입니다

translation.en: Dep Lead has verified those parameters. We are go with the motor move.
translation.ko: 차장님이 변수를 확인했습니다 모터 이동을 진행해도 좋습니다

translation.en: [Mike] If the wings of the primary mirror didn't latch,
they would actually vibrate in ways that we didn't want them to.
And that vibration would actually show up as a blurring of the image.
translation.ko: 그 진동 때문에 이미지가 흐릿하게 나타나겠죠

translation.en: [controller 3] We have reached our full preload, so at this time…
-[man] Oh, wow, that's it. -…we are go to proceed onto step 046
to enable and activate SCS-256.
[controller 4] Dep Ops, this is Dep Lead on deployment,
and those parameters look good.
[controller 5] Copy, proceeding with motor move.
[Thomas] Come on, ball. Pitch it in there.
-Look, it's starting to come out. -[man] You can see it moving. Yeah.
[Thomas] All right, we're almost halfway there at 54.
Look at that.
-[man] It's coming in. -[Thomas] Yeah. Keep going.
-Ninety-five now. Ninety-six. -[man] Yeah.
-There we go! -[man] Alright.
[all] Four…
three, two, one.
[controller 4] And we have a fully deployed JWST observatory.
translation.ko: 제임스 웹 우주 망원경 관측대가 완전히 배치됐습니다

translation.en: -[man 1] Whoo-hoo! -[man 2] Primary mirror.
-[Thomas] We're there! -[man 2] That sure looks beautiful.
[man 1] Yeah.
[Thomas] God Almighty.
[man 2] How hard was that?
-[Mike] I was looking for you, first. -[laughing]
[Thomas] Talk to me. How are you feeling?
[Mike chuckles] How the record is, it's been going smoother than we ever thought.
So to actually see it-- see it come together the way it did was beautiful.
[Scarlin] Everything went so smoothly, just really exciting.
Wanted to pop some champagne, but unfortunately, I didn't have any so…
translation.ko: 샴페인을 터뜨리고 싶은데 아쉽게도 지금 없네요

translation.en: [Thomas] I want to tell you just how excited and emotional I am right now.
translation.ko: 지금 얼마나 신나고 북받치는지 말하고 싶어요

translation.en: We have a deployed telescope on orbit.
translation.ko: 이제 궤도를 도는 배치 완료된 망원경이 생겼어요

translation.en: I personally appreciate your sacrifice
that you've given to this magnificent telescope,
the likes of which the world has never seen.
So how does it feel to make history, everybody?
[man laughs] It feels awesome!
[woman] JWST has completed all of its major deployments.
translation.ko: 제임스 웹 우주 망원경은 주요 배치를 전부 완료했어요

translation.en: Things are going spectacular.
We have the biggest, most complex observatory
translation.ko: 지금까지 우리가 우주에 보낸 것 중

translation.en: we've ever sent to space, and we can expect some awesome images.
translation.ko: 가장 크고 복잡한 관측대니까 근사한 이미지가 나올 거예요

translation.en: Y'all, we did it!
[Amber] It's hard to conceptualize what those first images will be.
translation.ko: 첫 이미지가 어떨지 개념화하는 것조차 어려워요

translation.en: I study how galaxies change over time,
translation.ko: 저는 은하가 시간이 지나면서 어떻게 변하는지 연구하니까

translation.en: so I'm interested in how stars form in galaxies,
translation.ko: 별들이 은하에서 어떻게 형성되고 블랙홀이 어떻게 만들어지며

translation.en: and how black holes form, and how those processes change over time.
translation.ko: 그런 과정이 시간에 따라 어떻게 변하는지에 관심이 있어요

translation.en: So, I am most excited for the deep field images.
translation.ko: 그래서 그런 딥 필드 이미지가 가장 기대돼요

translation.en: It's in these deep fields that we will be able to see the most distant galaxies.
translation.ko: 이런 딥 필드에서 가장 먼 은하를 볼 수 있거든요

translation.en: But it's about a million miles from Earth,
and there is definitely still a lot that could go wrong.
There always is.
[Mike] There are still 49 single point failure items that never go away.
translation.ko: 단일 장애 지점 49개는 여전히 계속 남아 있어요

translation.en: And if any of those single point failure items fails,
translation.ko: 그 단일 장애 지점 중 하나라도 실패하면

translation.en: we can lose the mission.
[announcer] An embarrassingly blurred Hubble Telescope.
One of the telescope's two mirrors is thought to be defective,
translation.ko: 망원경의 거울 두 개 중 하나에 결함이 있어서

translation.en: blurring its images.
The Hubble Space Telescope, we turn it on, it was out of focus.
translation.ko: 허블 우주 망원경을 켰더니 초점이 안 맞았어요

translation.en: The primary mirror, the focal length was wrong.
It was a disaster for many scientists that had counted on these images.
translation.ko: 이 사진을 기대했던 수많은 과학자에게 큰 재앙이었어요

translation.en: [Amber] To the astronomers working on it at the time, I can't imagine what--
what a letdown that was.
It was bad, you know? Even for me as a kid, I remember. Like, "Oh, no!"
translation.ko: 정말 안 좋았잖아요 어린 저조차 '저런!' 이랬거든요

translation.en: [man] Jeff, you'll have your hands full.
translation.ko: 제프, 손을 다 써야 할 테니

translation.en: You might wanna go ahead and put your helmet lights on.
Good idea.
[Thomas] Astronauts went up there and included a little optical piece.
translation.ko: 우주 비행사들이 올라가서 광학 부품을 넣었어요

translation.en: Almost a little-- Like, glasses, right, that fixed that focal length.
translation.ko: 그 초점 거리를 고쳐 주는 작은 안경 같은 거였죠

translation.en: -One bright pixel. -[man 1] Right there!
[man 3] There, there, there.
-[man 2] We can see the pixels. -We did it!
[Thomas] The hard part about Webb, it's too far away.
If there's any problem, we cannot send astronauts to fix it.
translation.ko: 문제가 생겨도 우주 비행사를 보내 고칠 수 없죠

translation.en: [Mike] We'll align the telescope.
Essentially, refocusing it.
That's a complicated process.
[Amber] The ghost of Hubble definitely haunts this team and has for decades.
translation.ko: 허블의 안 좋은 경험이 수십 년 동안 남아 팀을 괴롭혔죠

translation.en: [Mike] Many of my mentors were involved in Hubble.
translation.ko: 제 멘토 상당수가 허블 망원경에 참가했어요

translation.en: They all warned me about what that bad day is like.
translation.ko: 운수 나쁜 날이 어떤지 다들 저에게 경고했죠

translation.en: That it's public, it's visible, it's ugly, and you don't want to live through that.
translation.ko: 공개적이고 눈에 띄며 추악하고 그런 경험은 안 하는 게 좋아요

translation.en: So over the last few hours, we have taken a bunch of calibration data
translation.ko: 지난 몇 시간 동안 망원경의 상태를 측정하려고

translation.en: to measure the state of the telescope.
Literally none of us have looked at this yet.
translation.ko: 우리 중 그 누구도 못 본 자료죠

translation.en: There we go.
[man 1] Galaxies all over.
[woman] Galaxies.
[man 2] There are a lot more galaxies than there are stars.
It is just gorgeous and sharp.
This is how it's supposed to be.
[reporter] Six months after the most powerful telescope ever made launched into space,
translation.ko: 가장 강력한 망원경이 우주로 발사된 지 6개월 만에

translation.en: the team inside the Webb Space Telescope's flight control room is preparing
translation.ko: 웹 우주 망원경의 비행 통제실 속 팀원들은

translation.en: to reveal what astronomers all over the world
